hey guys, prototyping this psychosis risk calculator. it takes some environmental risk factors, along with baseline risk for any non-psychotic person with a relative with psychosis, and gives a probability for that person having a psychotic episode in the next few years. the numbers it computes are based on statistical models we’ve built and are honing, but i wanted your input on a way to visualize the output in an accessible way.
<https://kesh-lab.shinyapps.io/Meister-calc/>
Awesome! I will check it out
What's a Sig fig?
thanks! it’s very basic. up to now all the work has gone into getting the math to work, not the look. :blush:
oh, that won’t be in the final version, that was just so we could play with showing different numbers of digits
i don’t think anything more than 2 makes sense
anything more than that gives a false idea about how precise our model can get
woahhhhhhh
Heh, gotcha, I was worried, I eat a significant amount of figs daily
haha! yeah if we find that to be a risk factor i will let you know
so far, i think figs are okay
can you link the paper to the shiny app?
yes we will link paper -> app and app -> paper
right now the paper is in progress
coool! very interesting
i’m hoping to begin doing these with other papers where appropriate
cannabis is a risk factor for psychosis?
oh yes
one of the biggest
What's the "season"?
yeah it is

Environmental Risk Score: 2.798
Probability: 78.18 %
good question, that needs to be explained better - it’s interesting, we have found that winter and spring births are overrepresented in the psychosis population
Wow
these models are all being tested and retested as we get more data, so some things may get dropped, others added
we’re pushing to get access to some other large studies to validate with
Wiiild
I am very looking forward to reading the paper! This is very interesting.
So roughly how big is the set the current models were built on?
<@U066B6F9R|pavanb> has joined the channel
we did a bayesian model using a combination of epidemiological data and a sample of ~400 people at high risk for whom we had direct observations
~10% of those in our sample ended up converting to a psychotic disorder at sometime during follow-up
that corresponds pretty well the prevalence that’s been observed in people with a first degree relative with psychosis
~1% in general population, ~10% in first-degree relatives, and ~50% in monozygotic twins
Wild! One thought is that it's useful for exploring other conditions. instead of a percent probability, could you say 1 out of 10 people with these is likely to have an episode, for example?
To contextualize the percentage into something more palatable
hmmm so have 10 little grey people, and color them in depending on the % risk?
or did you mean spell it out in a sentence
Either way, something to make the percentage more real. It's kinda hard to map what that number might mean in terms of an individual life, but that social angle might make it easier to imagine
Just a thought, not totally sure what 1.867 of a person might looks like, but the general idea
sounds good, i think a sentence will be easy to do
for now
keep in mind these models need work. i’m just trying to get the interface ready
i’d also like a way to show the uncertainty somehow
kind of like error bars
No worries! Wouldn't share anything on this channel to public, safe place :)
whiteboarding some more ideas. thanks guys!
